title: Building An Open Source Linux Computing System On RISC-V

sentences.text: Abstract—As is commonly known, hardware in a computer system requires a processor to run the operating system.
The primary architectures that form the basis of most processors are CISC and RISC.
CISC includes long sub-level commands for effective memory management and simple compiler implementations to be developed.
Thus CISC has a complex set of commands; hence the name Complex Instruction Set Computer.
On the other hand, CISC has had backward compatibility since the 1970s.
Reduced Instruction Set Computer (RISC), the other popular architecture, simplifies command sets and handles access to memory with load-store commands.
Since the instruction set is simplified, the hardware runs faster.
In addition, RISC-based processors contain less chip-sets and may be designed faster.
Currently, with the prevalence of the Internet of Things (IoT), the demand for RISC architectures has increased and its usage in embedded devices has become widespread.
The ARM processor is a successful example of the RISC architecture adaptation.
However, ARM processor production has certain license term limitations and contains a few design flaws in its architecture [1].

In 2010, the RISC-V processor architecture, which was developed as an open source instruction set at Berkeley University, paves the way for open source hardware in terms of its BSD license and design professionalism.
As a result, it will be possible to produce their own processors for communities and organizations without license restrictions.
In this paper, we discuss the building blocks of the development life-cycle of an open source operating system on the RISC-V architecture.
As an operating system base, we implement MILIS Linux, an open source operating system development project.
It has an independent user space and its own package manager.
For a completely independent open source computing system, open source RISC-V hardware architecture provides the freedom that is needed.
A. RISC-V
In order to understand the RISC-V architectures that are used by current processor families, first it is essential to understand RISC.
These processors have a general set of instructions that are more homogeneous in length and execution time than CISC, which corresponds to more basic computational operations.
The implementation of the instructions is optimized and cluster command processing is used to increase the operating speed.
More register areas to minimize memory usage is included.
In order to achieve less memory and processing power, methods such as compression of the instruction set are utilized [2].
The disclosure of the Meltdown and Spectre vulnerabilities [1] shows that if we apply high security at software level, still weakness of computing resumes if we don't ensure at hardware level.
Processors are executing instructions in the computer with high-level access rights.
Some of the runtime conditions of the system are not visible, such as the Intel management engine [3].
In order to overcome this vulnerability, we have to make use of the open source synergy that Linux creates in the kernel on the hardware side.
Because the opening of ISA (Instruction Set Architecture), it can be discovered and improved by industry experts, commercial innovators and top academics.
The ability to add extensions to basic ISA makes it suitable for applications that require special configuration.
Although the processor market has been running for a long time, it has not been able to make great improvements, due to closed and license problems [4].

Although open source hardware studies have historically been conducted on Sparc [5] architectures or Power ISA [6] as open concepts, these projects have been insufficient and will not be able to create a large enough open source ecosystem.
Similarly, OpenRISC [7] is based on the open-source processor architecture OpenRISC1000.
Although Linux kernel 3.1 is supported, kernel-based improvements have slowed down over time.
Currently, though there is insufficient attention paid to these types of advances, Debian produced a port in 2014.
However, it closed the project due to copyright reasons in 2016.
But since UC-Berkeley started designing the RISC-V command set architecture, there has been new mobilization in academia and industry [8].
First of all, RISC-V is free and open source.
The usage license is licensed under the BSD license.
RISC-V primarily focuses on defining the command set architecture rather than specific implementations.
Still, there are also free open source core hardware designs [9].
RISC-V which is a nice leap for the processor sector has started to support many companies.
Technology relevant companies from many countries participated to RISC-V foundation.

Some major companies and institutes that contribute this foundation include; IIT Madras(India) [10], ETH Zurich(Swiss) [11], ASTC(Australia) [12], Barcelona Supercomputing Center(Spain) [13], ASELSAN(Turkey) [14].
By the way Western Digital also started to develop and use RISC-V architecture based processors in storage devices [15].
Unlike OpenRISC, RISC-V is aimed at a wider range of applications.
The Linux kernel's support for RISC-V is fairly new, starting with version 4.15 and 5.0 provides more extensive support, as well as RISC-V / Linux support for the kernel porting.
One of the outputs of RISC-V for hardware is to offer a more secure architecture and processor capabilities [12].
Due to the lack of speculative memory access in the RISC-V processor, there is no hardware weakness such as the Meltdown-Spectre vulnerability.
The most important advantage of RISC-V is that it is easy to apply qualified security ideas because the work is carried out as open source.
B. MILIS Linux
MILIS (Milli Isletim Sistemi in Turkish) [16] project is a Linux distribution project that started voluntarily in 2016 and implemented using LFS (Linux from Scratch) [17] techniques.
Since 2019, the project is supported by Akdeniz University BAP unit [18].
MILIS Linux differs from other GNU/Linux projects with its independent base and own package manager.
For the time being, a desktop-targeted operating system is being developed for x86-64 systems.
Target users of MILIS are, primarily government agencies, commercial organizations and private users.
It has the goal of being a free and easy to use operating system for individual and organizational use.
Unlike the other distributions, which is commonly forked from Debian, MILIS is not based on any existing Linux distribution.
It has its own package production collection and independent root file-system production.
It has open development platform for developers by providing pure Linux usage and development experience.
Secure network structure may easily be configured via a web browser.
Although the project has been initiated voluntarily, it has the ultimate goal of being an open source software ecosystem for the academic environment.
MILIS Linux project now aims to completely work on open source hardware and be one of the first in among Linux distributions.
Such open source hardware and operating system will have the benefit of being immune to world trade disputes such as the recent developments of Huawei product bans.
C. MILIS Linux and RISC-V
In order to achieve a completely open and secure system, related studies were followed and concluded that the RISC-V ISA study seem to be the most promising.
The members of the RISC-V foundation include some reputable companies including ASELSAN as a silver member.
ASELSAN and Bilkent University are collaborating to produce chips using RISC-V architecture [19].
Although R&D for chip production is ongoing, to our knowledge, we are not aware of any operating system work locally to support such architecture.
Globally, such work is also limited to few distributions.
To remedy this gap, we are developing a fork of the MILIS project to support RISC-V architecture.
In addition, it is desired to work as a separate branch for embedded devices.
It is expected that with an increasing interest in IoT and Industry 4.0, such software will likely have high interest.
Currently, Genpro from Israel [20] and Shakti [21] from India are working on new generation processors based on RISC-V architecture.
Recent interest in open processor architecture are likely to promote the open source operating systems.
The MILIS project is now planned to be one of the first open source Linux based OS targeting RISC-V.
With the RISC-V processor productions, Si-five has produced a number of development motherboards for developers [22].
Linux distributions on motherboards with these processors started to gain momentum.
Legacy distributions such as Debian have created a project group on the RISC-V and started porting as infrastructure transfer work [23].
Fedora develops a native OS by compiling packages targeting RISC-V.
It has also established a web-based compilation tracking system [24].
Apart from these, it can also produce minimal custom Linux images with Yocto [25] and Buildroot [26] Linux Kit.
Buildroot currently ported for 64-bit RISC-V architecture.
Buildroot supports RISC-V with native and original implementation.
In this paper, we will focus on increasing kernel support and reducing porting times by a proposed reference implementation based on MILIS.
We endeavored to build a Linux from Scratch from the root file system.
Also with the rapid integration of Linux distro developers, we can improve our user-space application level.
Currently, MILIS Linux is running smoothly with 64-bit systems.
Our RISC-V architecture-oriented work can be called a port in the Linux community.
Port aims to produce kernel and userspace packages available in MILIS and a hardware based 64-bit little-endian RISC-V compatible base system.
RISC-V also allows 32-bit and 128-bit ISA configurations, however the development of other variants will be considered as future work.
• 32-bit architectures, except for specific purposes;
• 32-bit ports in MILIS have never been done, it is not necessary.
• 128-bit operation is not realistic at this time.
Since MILIS is a Linux system that applies the Linux from Scratch directives, similar methods can be used to build the basis of the RISC-V architecture.
In this section, we detail the work packages that are typically included in porting.
A. System Emulation
RISC-V system emulator may be used during the development and testing of the OS without real hardware.
Low cost easy setup QEMU virtual machine [27] supports RISC-V since 2.12.
This is opposite of QEMU's full system emulation mode, which ensures emulation devices and requires you to boot an operating system natively.
We use QEMU 4.0.0 version.
B. Toolchain
Toolchain is a cross-compiler for GNU.
RISC-V requires Binutils 2.30 or above versions to build a kernel with GCC 7.1 or above.
Currently, we choose GCC 9.1 and Binutils 2.32 versions.
There are 3 common C libraries; Glibc, Uclibc and Musl.
Only Glibc has upstream RISC-V support for 64-bit only architecture.
We choose Glibc version 2.29 to build packages [28].
C. Bootloader
A bootloader is a piece of code that executes before an operating system runs.
Bootloaders usually provide several options to boot the OS kernel and also contain commands for debugging and/or modifying the kernel environment before booting.
RISC-V specific Berkley Bootloader(BBL) may be used in this project [29].
U-boot may be another alternative, but requires more work for porting to RISC-V.
BBL will support;
• Starting and response tasks to timer interrupts,
• Boot chain loading for Linux and default boot loading process,
• RISC-V processor is not equipped to handle some instructions directly in hardware so BBL handles them as well.
BBL is somewhat special in that it cannot chainload a Linux kernel like GRUB or U-Boot, but instead the BBL compile scripts links the kernel binary directly into the BBL ELF file.
Therefore BBL must always be rebuilt within kernel.
Creating a proper separation between BBL and the kernel is planned but not yet implemented.
RISC-V Linux port has been accepted into Linux tree and is slated to release as part of 4.15 since 2017.
While this is a major milestone, still much work remains related to the Linux kernel and the userspace.
Additionally, much research and many tasks remain in the following areas:
• Init and Halt Code
• Atomic and Locking Code
• Generic library routines and assembly
• ELF and module implementation
• Task implementation
• Device, timer, IRQs, and the SBI
• Paging and MMU
• User-facing API
• Build Infrastructure
For building the kernel, we used the 5.0 stable version from the kernel git repository [30] using the following compilation parameters; CROSSCOMPILE=riscv64-linuxgnu- ARCH=riscv.
And BBL will compile with -withpayload config parameter to reference compiled kernel.
E. Pre-Root File System and Package Production
We cross-compile packages from x86-64 host to riscv64 target file system.
At the conclusion of this process, we were able to achieve a bootable operating system for RISC-V hardware or an emulator.
This root filesystem, named prerootfs, will be used at package production.
After producing the necessary packages, we will re-construct the base file system of RISC-V using these packages.
F. Bootable Image
Recreation of Rootfs using MILIS enables us to distribute an initial bootable binary disk image that is completely built from MILIS packages for kernel and user space software.
With adding live system packages, we will get a live image to run a virtual board.
Fig. 1 shows the general workflow that is applied during the building of the RISC-V computing environment.
In this paper, the RISC-V processor has been compared to other architectures and its bright future was implied.
Being opensource and its community driven design through open source hardware initiative, it may be used in mission critical projects.
Especially with the advances in the Internet of Things, the use of RISC-V processor boards may likely become popular in the market with the exciting features it provides.
Because many companies have started R&D studies for RISC-V and become members of the RISC-V foundation.
In addition to hardware information, this open source hardware that we have emphasized in this paper is the necessity of developing an open source and reliable operating system.
In this case, Linux is the best candidate on the basis of this work as the kernel.

Even though port migration of different Linux distributions has already begun, we are stressing the need to create an open source and reliable user ecosystem directly on the Linux kernel by enabling the MILIS Linux project to be ported to a different architecture.
Any development and optimization in this process will add experience to our IT process.
This study will gain momentum with the open computing proposal and will gain more.
A. Physical Implementation and Optimizations
The work outline performed on the QEMU virtual machine discussed in this study will be applied on a real board based on RISC-V processor.
Compilation and testing will give more accurate results using physical hardware.
Thus, we will have a better understanding of the components that will need to be optimized.
The compilation tools that we use in the bootstrap process will offer more RISC-V support over time and will be optimized.
In addition, alternative libraries instead of Glibc, which we currently use as C libraries, will be evaluated.
Also, with the RISC-V support in the LLVM Compiler Infrastructure [31], native compile support will be increased at the level of programming languages which use LLVM as back-end compiler.
RISC-V porting will be further explored for the kernel level difficulties encountered while providing the necessary solutions.

The necessary sponsors and research project funding supports will be provided for the R&D studies and RISC-V processors with different features will be obtained and the studies will be performed on real equipment.
B. The Future: Open Hardware and Open Source Operating System
Open hardware means license-free; namely with RISC-V virtually anyone can produce potentially better evaluations and much more accurate comparisons with existing works.
There is a range of high quality, open-source RISC-V implementations to modify, rather than just based on estimating or simulations.
Also opening standard will bring about a more active development community so that when sharing patches or ideas, projects will get contributions more quickly.
As of now one aspect of the RISC-V Foundation is responding to proposals and discussing them.
The other aspect is producing proposed changes either in a future specification revision or in hardware.
On the other hand, opening the standards and having a commercially open license would certainly make the processor design and production race more fair.

Also RISC-V will bring a new synergy of open source computer architecture research areas, such as universities started to establish research groups on RISC-V, such as OpenCelerity [32] and SCARV [33].
Research is expected to be carried out on real hardware with the increase of RISC-V processor manufacturers.
As a result, Linux kernel and userspace seems the best candidate software stack for RISC-V.

Entity-the_development_of_other_variant.description: The development of other variants refers to the future work planned for creating additional instruction set architecture (ISA) configurations for RISC-V, specifically the 32-bit and 128-bit variants beyond the currently implemented 64-bit system.

Entity-porting_time.label: porting times
Entity-porting_time.description: Porting times refer to the duration required to adapt and compile software, particularly Linux distributions, for compatibility with the RISC-V architecture.

Entity-the_usage_license.label: The usage license
Entity-the_usage_license.description: The usage license refers to the BSD license under which the RISC-V instruction set architecture is licensed, allowing for open source development and implementation without restrictions.

Entity-init_and_halt_code.label: Init and Halt Code
Entity-init_and_halt_code.description: Init and Halt Code refers to a specific segment of system code responsible for initializing and terminating processes within the RISC-V Linux operating system environment.

Entity-experience.label: experience
Entity-experience.description: In this context, 'experience' refers to the accumulated knowledge and skills gained through the development and optimization processes involved in the IT project related to the RISC-V architecture and the MILIS Linux operating system.

Entity-exciting_feature.label: exciting features
Entity-exciting_feature.description: The term 'exciting features' refers to the innovative capabilities and advantages offered by RISC-V processor boards, particularly in the context of their open-source nature and suitability for mission-critical applications in the rapidly evolving Internet of Things landscape.

Entity-the_kernel.label: the kernel
Entity-the_kernel.description: The kernel refers to the core component of the Linux operating system that manages hardware resources and facilitates communication between software and hardware, particularly in the context of supporting RISC-V architecture.

Entity-x86-64.label: x86-64
Entity-x86-64.description: x86-64 is a 64-bit instruction set architecture used in computer processors, extending the x86 architecture to support larger amounts of memory and enhanced performance.

Entity-user_ecosystem.label: user ecosystem
Entity-user_ecosystem.description: The 'user ecosystem' refers to the open source and reliable environment for users that is being developed around the MILIS Linux project, which aims to provide a stable and adaptable operating system experience on the RISC-V architecture.

Entity-the_necessary_package.label: the necessary packages
Entity-the_necessary_package.description: The necessary packages refer to the software components that are cross-compiled from an x86-64 host to create a bootable operating system and reconstruct the base file system for RISC-V architecture.

Entity-open_source_synergy.label: open source synergy
Entity-open_source_synergy.description: Open source synergy refers to the collaborative and integrative approach that Linux fosters between software and hardware development, enabling improvements and innovations in open source hardware architectures like RISC-V.

Entity-many_company.label: many companies
Entity-many_company.description: The term 'many companies' refers to a diverse group of technology-related organizations from various countries that are participating in the RISC-V foundation to support the development and implementation of the RISC-V open source processor architecture.

Entity-version.label: versions
Entity-version.description: In the context of this paper, 'versions' refers to specific releases of software tools and libraries, such as GCC and Binutils, that are required for building and compiling the RISC-V architecture-based operating system.

Entity-extension.label: extensions
Entity-extension.description: In the context of RISC-V architecture, 'extensions' refer to additional features or modifications that can be integrated into the basic Instruction Set Architecture (ISA) to tailor it for specific applications or requirements.

Entity-branch.label: branch
Entity-branch.description: In this context, 'branch' refers to a separate development pathway or version of the MILIS Linux project that is specifically tailored for embedded devices using the RISC-V architecture.

Entity-few_distribution.label: few distributions
Entity-few_distribution.description: The term 'few distributions' refers to the limited number of operating system distributions that currently support the RISC-V architecture, highlighting a gap in the availability of such systems in the global market.

Entity-producing_proposed_change.label: producing proposed changes
Entity-producing_proposed_change.description: Producing proposed changes refers to the process of developing and implementing modifications or enhancements to specifications or hardware designs within the context of open-source RISC-V architecture.

Entity-device__timer__irqs__and_the_sbi.label: Device, timer, IRQs, and the SBI
aliases: Device, timer, IRQs, and the SBI
Entity-device__timer__irqs__and_the_sbi.description: The mention 'Device, timer, IRQs, and the SBI' refers to essential components and functionalities within the RISC-V architecture that are critical for managing hardware interactions, specifically focusing on device management, timer operations, interrupt request handling, and the Supervisor Binary Interface (SBI) for system-level operations.

Entity-x86-64_host.label: x86-64 host
Entity-x86-64_host.description: An x86-64 host refers to a computer system that utilizes the x86-64 architecture, which is a 64-bit extension of the x86 instruction set, and is used as the platform for cross-compiling software packages to be run on RISC-V target systems.

Entity-open_source_computer_architecture.label: open source computer architecture research areas
aliases: open source computer architecture research areas
Entity-open_source_computer_architecture.description: Open source computer architecture research areas refer to collaborative fields of study focused on the development and innovation of computer architectures, particularly those that utilize open source principles, exemplified by initiatives like RISC-V and associated university research groups.

Entity-r__d_for_chip_production.label: R&D for chip production
Entity-r__d_for_chip_production.description: R&D for chip production refers to the research and development activities focused on designing, creating, and improving semiconductor chips, particularly in the context of implementing the RISC-V architecture for various applications.

Entity-version_4.15.label: version 4.15
Entity-version_4.15.description: Version 4.15 refers to a specific release of the Linux kernel that introduced initial support for the RISC-V architecture.

Entity-task_implementation.label: Task implementation
Entity-task_implementation.description: Task implementation refers to the process of executing and managing various tasks necessary for the development and integration of the RISC-V Linux operating system, including areas such as atomic and locking code, device management, and user-facing APIs.

Entity-market.label: market
Entity-market.description: The term 'market' refers to the business environment where RISC-V processor boards are expected to gain popularity due to advancements in the Internet of Things and their appealing features.

Entity-x86-64_system.label: x86-64 systems
Entity-x86-64_system.description: x86-64 systems refer to a family of computer architectures based on the x86 instruction set that support 64-bit processing, commonly used in modern desktop and server hardware.

Entity-kernel_support.label: kernel support
Entity-kernel_support.description: Kernel support refers to the functionality and enhancements provided by the operating system kernel to improve compatibility and performance for software applications running on RISC-V architecture.

Entity-sbi.label: SBI
Entity-sbi.description: SBI refers to the Supervisor Binary Interface, which is a protocol that facilitates communication between the operating system and the hardware in RISC-V architecture.

Entity-a_better_understanding.label: a better understanding
Entity-a_better_understanding.description: The term 'a better understanding' refers to the enhanced insight into the specific components of the RISC-V architecture that require optimization, gained through practical testing and compilation on physical hardware.

Entity-simulation.label: simulations
Entity-simulation.description: The term 'simulations' refers to the computational models or approximations used to estimate the performance and behavior of RISC-V implementations, which are being contrasted with actual high-quality open-source implementations that can be modified.

Entity-an_emulator.label: an emulator
Entity-an_emulator.description: An emulator is a software tool that allows the execution of an operating system or application designed for one hardware architecture, such as RISC-V, on a different hardware architecture by simulating the original hardware's functionality.

Entity-this_study_(1).label: this study
Entity-this_study_(1).description: This study refers to the research and development work conducted on the QEMU virtual machine, which will be applied to a real board utilizing the RISC-V processor architecture.

Entity-license-free.label: license-free
Entity-license-free.description: The term 'license-free' refers to the ability to produce and modify hardware, specifically in the context of RISC-V architecture, without the constraints of licensing restrictions, allowing for greater accessibility and innovation in hardware development.

Entity-a_major_milestone.label: a major milestone
Entity-a_major_milestone.description: A major milestone refers to the acceptance of the RISC-V Linux port into the Linux kernel tree, marking a significant achievement in the development of an open source operating system for the RISC-V architecture.

Entity-compilation_and_testing.label: Compilation and testing
Entity-compilation_and_testing.description: Compilation and testing refers to the process of building software from source code and verifying its functionality on physical hardware, which enhances the accuracy of performance results and optimizations in the context of developing an open source operating system on RISC-V architecture.

Entity-qualified_security_idea.label: qualified security ideas
Entity-qualified_security_idea.description: Qualified security ideas refer to security concepts and practices that can be easily implemented within the RISC-V architecture due to its open-source nature, allowing for enhanced security measures to be integrated at both hardware and software levels.

Entity-processor.label: processor
Entity-processor.description: A processor is a critical hardware component in a computer system that executes instructions and processes data, enabling the operation of software applications and the operating system.

Entity-infrastructure_transfer_work.label: infrastructure transfer work
Entity-infrastructure_transfer_work.description: Infrastructure transfer work refers to the efforts undertaken by legacy Linux distributions, such as Debian, to port their systems to the RISC-V architecture, facilitating the adaptation and integration of these operating systems on new hardware platforms.

Entity-2017.description: The mention '2017' refers to the year when the RISC-V Linux port was accepted into the Linux kernel tree and is scheduled for release as part of version 4.15.

Entity-power_isa.label: Power ISA
Entity-power_isa.description: Power ISA is an instruction set architecture developed by IBM for its Power processors, designed to support high-performance computing and embedded systems.

Entity-compilation.label: Compilation
Entity-compilation.description: Compilation refers to the process of translating source code into executable code, which is essential for testing and optimizing software on physical hardware in the context of RISC-V architecture development.

Entity-gcc_7.1.label: GCC 7.1
Entity-gcc_7.1.description: GCC 7.1 refers to version 7.1 of the GNU Compiler Collection, a widely used open-source compiler system that supports various programming languages and is essential for building software, including kernels for RISC-V architecture.

Entity-proposal.label: proposals
Entity-proposal.description: The term 'proposals' refers to suggestions or recommendations made to the RISC-V Foundation regarding changes or improvements in specifications or hardware related to the RISC-V architecture.

Entity-license_restriction.label: license restrictions
Entity-license_restriction.description: License restrictions refer to legal limitations imposed on the use, modification, and distribution of software or hardware, which in this context highlights the absence of such limitations in the production of processors based on the open-source RISC-V architecture.

Entity-port_migration_of_different_linux.label: port migration of different Linux distributions

Entity-compiled_kernel.label: compiled kernel
Entity-compiled_kernel.description: The 'compiled kernel' refers to the Linux kernel that has been built specifically for the RISC-V architecture, which is referenced in the context of using the Berkley Bootloader (BBL) to integrate the kernel binary into the bootloader's ELF file.

Entity-proposed_change.label: proposed changes
Entity-proposed_change.description: The term 'proposed changes' refers to modifications suggested for future revisions of specifications or hardware related to the RISC-V architecture.

Entity-the_compilation_tool.label: The compilation tools
Entity-the_compilation_tool.description: The compilation tools refer to software utilities used in the bootstrap process of building an open source operating system on RISC-V architecture, which are designed to enhance support for RISC-V and undergo optimization over time.

Entity-gcc.label: GCC
Entity-gcc.description: GCC refers to the GNU Compiler Collection, a set of programming language compilers that is used to build software, including kernels for the RISC-V architecture.

Entity-many_country.label: many countries
Entity-many_country.description: The term 'many countries' refers to the various nations whose technology-related companies have joined the RISC-V foundation to contribute to the development of the RISC-V open source processor architecture.

Entity-opencelerity.label: OpenCelerity
Entity-opencelerity.description: OpenCelerity is a research group established by universities focused on open source computer architecture, specifically related to the RISC-V instruction set.

Entity-atomic_and_locking_code.label: Atomic and Locking Code
Entity-atomic_and_locking_code.description: Atomic and Locking Code refers to a critical section of code in the RISC-V Linux port that ensures safe and synchronized access to shared resources in a multi-threaded environment.

Entity-such_work.label: such work
Entity-such_work.description: The term 'such work' refers to the limited global efforts in developing operating systems that support the RISC-V architecture.

Entity-effective_memory_management.label: effective memory management
Entity-effective_memory_management.description: Effective memory management refers to the strategies and techniques employed in computer architecture, particularly in CISC, to optimize the use of memory resources through the implementation of complex command sets that facilitate efficient data handling and compiler operations.

Entity-necessary_solution.label: necessary solutions
Entity-necessary_solution.description: Necessary solutions refer to the specific technical approaches and methodologies required to address kernel-level challenges in the RISC-V architecture during the porting process.

Entity-the_market.label: the market
Entity-the_market.description: In this context, 'the market' refers to the commercial landscape and demand for RISC-V processor boards, particularly in relation to their increasing popularity and application in Internet of Things (IoT) projects.

Entity-5.0.description: 5.0 refers to a version of the Linux kernel that offers enhanced support for the RISC-V architecture.

Entity-a_free_and_easy_to_use_operating_.label: a free and easy to use operating system
aliases: a free and easy to use operating system
Entity-a_free_and_easy_to_use_operating_.description: The term 'a free and easy to use operating system' refers to MILIS Linux, a Linux distribution project designed to provide an independent, user-friendly operating system for both individual and organizational use, developed using Linux from Scratch techniques.

Entity-simple_compiler_implementation.label: simple compiler implementations
Entity-simple_compiler_implementation.description: Simple compiler implementations refer to straightforward and less complex compiler designs that can be developed to effectively manage memory in CISC architectures.

Entity-development_motherboards.label: development motherboards
Entity-development_motherboards.description: Development motherboards refer to specialized hardware platforms produced by SiFive that are designed for developers to create and test applications on RISC-V processors.

Entity-recreation_of_rootfs.label: Recreation of Rootfs
Entity-recreation_of_rootfs.description: Recreation of Rootfs refers to the process of constructing a bootable binary disk image for a RISC-V system, utilizing packages from the MILIS Linux operating system to create a complete environment for kernel and user space software.

Entity-many_task.label: many tasks
Entity-many_task.description: The term 'many tasks' refers to the various research and development activities that are necessary for the continued advancement and implementation of the RISC-V Linux port, including areas such as code implementation, device management, and system infrastructure.

Entity-better_evaluation.label: better evaluations
Entity-better_evaluation.description: Better evaluations refer to the enhanced assessments and comparisons of RISC-V hardware implementations that can be achieved due to the open-source nature of the architecture, allowing for more accurate and reliable results compared to existing works.

Entity-kernel-based_improvement.label: kernel-based improvements
Entity-kernel-based_improvement.description: Kernel-based improvements refer to enhancements and optimizations made to the Linux kernel to support various functionalities and performance improvements, particularly in the context of open source hardware architectures like RISC-V.

Entity-7.1.description: 7.1 refers to the version of the GCC (GNU Compiler Collection) required for building a kernel in the RISC-V architecture, specifically indicating that GCC version 7.1 or above is necessary.

Entity-this_project.label: this project
Entity-this_project.description: This project refers to the development and implementation of the RISC-V specific Berkley Bootloader (BBL) as part of the MILIS Linux operating system tailored for RISC-V architecture.

Entity-chip-sets.label: chip-sets
Entity-chip-sets.description: Chip-sets are electronic components that integrate multiple functions and circuits onto a single chip, commonly used in computer hardware to manage communication between the processor and other components.

Entity-the_work_outline.label: the work outline
Entity-the_work_outline.description: The work outline refers to the structured plan or framework detailing the tasks and methodologies to be implemented in the study, specifically regarding the application of virtual machine experiments on actual RISC-V hardware.

Entity-default_boot_loading_process.label: default boot loading process
Entity-default_boot_loading_process.description: The default boot loading process refers to the sequence of operations performed by a bootloader, specifically in the context of loading the Linux operating system on RISC-V architecture, which includes initializing the system and transferring control to the operating system kernel.

Entity-web-based_compilation_tracking_sy.label: web-based compilation tracking system
Entity-web-based_compilation_tracking_sy.description: The web-based compilation tracking system is a software tool developed to monitor and manage the compilation processes of Linux distributions specifically targeting RISC-V architecture, facilitating efficient tracking and coordination among developers.

Entity-qemu_virtual_machine.label: QEMU virtual machine
Entity-qemu_virtual_machine.description: A QEMU virtual machine is a software-based emulator that allows users to run RISC-V architecture systems on virtualized hardware, facilitating development and testing without the need for physical hardware.

Entity-general_workflow.label: general workflow
Entity-general_workflow.description: The 'general workflow' refers to the systematic process illustrated in Fig. 1, which outlines the steps involved in constructing the RISC-V computing environment, including the integration of various components such as system emulation, toolchain setup, bootloader configuration, and package production.

Entity-testing.label: testing
Entity-testing.description: In this context, 'testing' refers to the process of evaluating and verifying the functionality and performance of software and hardware components on physical RISC-V architecture to ensure accurate results.

Entity-64-bit_system.label: 64-bit systems
Entity-64-bit_system.description: 64-bit systems refer to computer architectures that utilize a 64-bit wide data bus, allowing for the processing of data and memory addresses in 64-bit chunks, which enhances performance and enables the use of larger amounts of RAM compared to 32-bit systems.

Entity-crosscompileriscv64-linuxgnu-.label: CROSSCOMPILE=riscv64-linuxgnu-
Entity-crosscompileriscv64-linuxgnu-.description: CROSSCOMPILE=riscv64-linuxgnu- is a compilation parameter used to specify the prefix for the cross-compiler toolchain targeting the RISC-V architecture, enabling the building of software for RISC-V systems from a different host architecture.

Entity-risc-v_specific_berkley_bootloade.label: RISC-V specific Berkley Bootloader(BBL)
Entity-risc-v_specific_berkley_bootloade.description: The RISC-V specific Berkeley Bootloader (BBL) is a specialized bootloader designed for RISC-V architecture that facilitates the booting process of Linux by directly linking the kernel binary into its ELF file, enabling essential tasks such as timer interrupt handling and boot chain loading.

Entity-project_group.label: project group
Entity-project_group.description: The 'project group' refers to a collaborative initiative established by legacy Linux distributions, such as Debian, to facilitate the porting of their operating systems to the RISC-V architecture.

Entity-milli_isletim_sistemi.label: Milli Isletim Sistemi
Entity-milli_isletim_sistemi.description: Milli Isletim Sistemi, or MILIS, is a Linux distribution project initiated in 2016 that utilizes Linux from Scratch techniques, featuring an independent base and its own package manager, aimed at providing a free and user-friendly operating system for both individual and organizational use.

Entity-root_file-system_production.label: root file-system production
Entity-root_file-system_production.description: The term 'root file-system production' refers to the process of creating an independent file system structure for the MILIS Linux operating system, which is designed to operate without reliance on existing Linux distributions.

Entity-starting_and_response_task.label: Starting and response tasks
Entity-starting_and_response_task.description: Starting and response tasks refer to the operations performed by the bootloader to manage timer interrupts during the boot process of the RISC-V architecture.

Entity-open_source_operating_system.label: Open Source Operating System
Entity-open_source_operating_system.description: An Open Source Operating System is a type of software that manages computer hardware and software resources and is made available with source code that can be modified and distributed by anyone.

Entity-5.0_stable_version.label: 5.0 stable version
Entity-5.0_stable_version.description: The '5.0 stable version' refers to a specific release of the Linux kernel used in the development of the MILIS Linux operating system for RISC-V architecture.

Entity-kernel_level_difficulty.label: kernel level difficulties
Entity-kernel_level_difficulty.description: Kernel level difficulties refer to the technical challenges and issues faced during the adaptation and optimization of the Linux kernel for the RISC-V architecture.

Entity-intel_management_engine.label: Intel management engine
Entity-intel_management_engine.description: The Intel Management Engine is a hardware-based subsystem integrated into Intel chipsets that provides various management and security features, operating independently of the main CPU and operating system.

Entity-much_research.label: much research
Entity-much_research.description: The term 'much research' refers to the extensive ongoing investigation and development efforts required to address various technical challenges and tasks related to the RISC-V Linux port, including areas such as kernel implementation, user-space functionality, and system architecture enhancements.

Entity-32-bit.label: 32-bit
Entity-32-bit.description: 32-bit refers to a computer architecture configuration that uses 32 bits for data representation and processing, commonly associated with instruction set architectures and data types in computing systems.

Entity-more_accurate_comparison.label: more accurate comparisons
Entity-more_accurate_comparison.description: The term 'more accurate comparisons' refers to the enhanced ability to evaluate and contrast the performance and features of RISC-V implementations against existing hardware and software solutions, facilitated by the open-source nature of RISC-V which allows for real hardware testing and modifications.

Entity-128-bit.label: 128-bit
Entity-128-bit.description: 128-bit refers to a data width or architecture configuration that allows for the processing of data in 128-bit chunks, commonly used in computer systems and instruction set architectures to enhance performance and efficiency.

Entity-the_computer.label: the computer
Entity-the_computer.description: The computer refers to a system that utilizes processors to execute instructions, enabling the operation of software and management of hardware resources.

Entity-the_hardware_side.label: the hardware side
Entity-the_hardware_side.description: The hardware side refers to the physical components and architecture of computer systems, specifically in the context of utilizing open source principles to enhance security and functionality in processor design and implementation.

Entity-the_1970s.label: the 1970s
Entity-the_1970s.description: The 1970s refers to the decade spanning from January 1, 1970, to December 31, 1979, during which significant developments in computer architecture, particularly the establishment of backward compatibility in Complex Instruction Set Computers (CISC), occurred.

Entity-open_source_computing_system.label: open source computing system
Entity-open_source_computing_system.description: An open source computing system is a computing framework or platform that allows users to access, modify, and distribute its source code freely, promoting collaboration and innovation in software development.

Entity-elf_and_module_implementation.label: ELF and module implementation
Entity-elf_and_module_implementation.description: The 'ELF and module implementation' refers to the process of integrating the Executable and Linkable Format (ELF) for binary files and the management of loadable modules within the RISC-V Linux operating system, which is essential for enabling dynamic loading and execution of software components.

Entity-milis.label: MILIS
Entity-milis.description: MILIS is a Linux distribution project initiated in 2016, developed using Linux from Scratch techniques, and features an independent base and its own package manager.

Entity-berkley_bootloader.label: Berkley Bootloader
Entity-berkley_bootloader.description: The Berkley Bootloader (BBL) is a RISC-V specific bootloader designed to execute before an operating system runs, providing essential boot options and handling certain instructions that the RISC-V processor cannot manage directly in hardware.

Entity-irqs.label: IRQs
Entity-irqs.description: IRQs, or interrupt requests, are signals sent to the processor by hardware or software indicating that an event needs immediate attention, allowing the CPU to prioritize and manage multiple tasks efficiently.

Entity-the_following_area.label: the following areas
Entity-the_following_area.description: The term 'the following areas' refers to specific research and development tasks related to the RISC-V Linux port, including Init and Halt Code, Atomic and Locking Code, Generic library routines and assembly, ELF and module implementation, Task implementation, Device, timer, IRQs, and the SBI, Paging and MMU, User-facing API, and Build Infrastructure.

Entity-2.30.description: The mention '2.30' refers to the version number of the Binutils software package, which is required for building a kernel compatible with RISC-V architecture.

Entity-module_implementation.label: module implementation
Entity-module_implementation.description: The term 'module implementation' refers to the process of integrating and managing software modules within the context of the RISC-V Linux port, specifically focusing on the implementation of the Executable and Linkable Format (ELF) for handling modular components in the operating system.

Entity-this_root_filesystem.label: This root filesystem
Entity-this_root_filesystem.description: This root filesystem, referred to as prerootfs, is a foundational filesystem created for the purpose of cross-compiling packages and reconstructing the base filesystem of a RISC-V operating system.

Entity-specific_purpose.label: specific purposes
Entity-specific_purpose.description: The term 'specific purposes' refers to particular applications or use cases for which 32-bit architectures may be utilized, distinguishing them from the general development focus on 64-bit systems in the context of the MILIS Linux project on RISC-V.

Entity-software_stack.label: software stack
Entity-software_stack.description: A software stack is a collection of software components that work together to provide a complete solution for a specific computing environment, typically including an operating system, middleware, and application software.

Entity-hardware_in_a_computer_system.label: hardware in a computer system
Entity-hardware_in_a_computer_system.description: Hardware in a computer system refers to the physical components, including the processor, that are essential for the operation and functionality of the system, enabling it to run software and manage tasks.

Entity-operating_system.label: operating system
Entity-operating_system.description: An operating system is a collection of software that manages computer hardware and provides services for computer programs, serving as an intermediary between users and the computer hardware.

Entity-processor_family.label: processor families
Entity-processor_family.description: Processor families refer to groups of related microprocessor designs that share a common architecture and instruction set, typically produced by a single manufacturer.

Entity-bbl.label: BBL
Entity-bbl.description: BBL refers to the Berkeley Bootloader, a specialized bootloader for RISC-V architecture that directly links the Linux kernel binary into its ELF file, distinguishing it from other bootloaders like GRUB or U-Boot.

Entity-milis_linux_project.label: MILIS Linux project
Entity-milis_linux_project.description: The MILIS Linux project is a voluntary initiative that began in 2016 to develop a unique Linux distribution using Linux from Scratch techniques, featuring its own package manager and independent base, aimed at providing a free and user-friendly operating system primarily for government agencies, commercial organizations, and private users.

Entity-linux.label: Linux
Entity-linux.description: Linux is a widely used open source operating system kernel that serves as the foundation for various operating systems and software distributions.

Entity-original_implementation.label: original implementation
Entity-original_implementation.description: The term 'original implementation' refers to the foundational version of Buildroot that is specifically designed to support the RISC-V architecture.

Entity-specification_revision.label: specification revision
Entity-specification_revision.description: The term 'specification revision' refers to the process of proposing and implementing changes to the existing technical specifications of the RISC-V architecture, which may involve updates to the standards governing its design and functionality.

Entity-minimal_custom_linux_image.label: minimal custom Linux images
Entity-minimal_custom_linux_image.description: Minimal custom Linux images refer to lightweight and tailored Linux operating system images created using tools like Yocto and Buildroot, designed to meet specific requirements for RISC-V architecture development boards.

Entity-shakti.label: Shakti
Entity-shakti.description: Shakti refers to a company from India that is developing new generation processors based on the RISC-V architecture.

Entity-native_o.label: native OS
Entity-native_o.description: A native OS is an operating system specifically designed to run on a particular hardware architecture or platform, utilizing its features and capabilities.

Entity-32-bit_architecture.label: 32-bit architectures
Entity-32-bit_architecture.description: 32-bit architectures refer to computer architectures that use a 32-bit wide data bus, allowing for the processing of data in 32-bit chunks, which influences the amount of memory that can be addressed and the performance of computing systems.

Entity-the_intel_management_engine.label: the Intel management engine
Entity-the_intel_management_engine.description: The Intel Management Engine is a proprietary subsystem integrated into Intel chipsets that operates independently of the main CPU, providing various management and security features, including remote management capabilities and system monitoring.

Entity-bootable_operating_system.label: bootable operating system
Entity-bootable_operating_system.description: A bootable operating system is a type of system software that is capable of being loaded and executed by a computer's hardware to manage resources and provide a platform for running applications.

Entity-research_project_funding_support.label: research project funding supports
Entity-research_project_funding_support.description: Research project funding supports refer to the financial resources and sponsorships allocated to facilitate research and development activities, particularly in the context of acquiring RISC-V processors and conducting studies on physical hardware.

Entity-o_kernel.label: OS kernel
Entity-o_kernel.description: The OS kernel is the core component of an operating system that manages system resources and facilitates communication between hardware and software.

Entity-live_system_package.label: live system packages
Entity-live_system_package.description: Live system packages refer to software components that are included in the MILIS Linux operating system to create a live image, enabling the system to run directly from a virtual board without installation.

Entity-2.12.description: The mention '2.12' refers to the version of QEMU that introduced support for RISC-V architecture.

Entity-high-level_access_right.label: high-level access rights
Entity-high-level_access_right.description: High-level access rights refer to the elevated permissions granted to processors that allow them to execute instructions and access system resources at a privileged level, essential for managing critical operations and ensuring security within a computing environment.

Entity-b._milis_linux.label: B. MILIS Linux
Entity-b._milis_linux.description: B. MILIS Linux is an independent Linux distribution project initiated in 2016, designed using Linux from Scratch techniques, featuring its own package manager and targeting primarily government agencies and commercial organizations, with a goal of providing a free and user-friendly operating system for both individual and organizational use.

Entity-estimating_or_simulation.label: estimating or simulations
Entity-estimating_or_simulation.description: Estimating or simulations refer to the methods used to predict or model the performance and behavior of RISC-V implementations, which can be less accurate compared to actual physical hardware evaluations.

Entity-will_be_optimized.label: will be optimized
Entity-will_be_optimized.description: The term 'will be optimized' refers to the enhancement and improvement of compilation tools used in the bootstrap process to provide increased support for the RISC-V architecture over time.

Entity-open_source_hardware_study.label: open source hardware studies
Entity-open_source_hardware_study.description: Open source hardware studies refer to research and analysis focused on the principles, practices, and implications of hardware designs that are made publicly available for use, modification, and distribution by anyone.

Entity-open_concept.label: open concepts
Entity-open_concept.description: Open concepts refer to theoretical frameworks and methodologies in open source hardware studies, particularly those related to architectures like Sparc and Power ISA, which have historically aimed to foster an open source ecosystem but have faced limitations in their effectiveness.

Entity-open_source_hardware.label: open source hardware
Entity-open_source_hardware.description: Open source hardware refers to physical devices and systems whose design specifications are made publicly available, allowing anyone to study, modify, distribute, and manufacture them.

Entity-estimating.label: estimating
Entity-estimating.description: In this context, 'estimating' refers to the process of making approximations or assessments regarding the performance or characteristics of RISC-V implementations, as opposed to relying solely on simulations.

Entity-version_2.29.label: version 2.29
Entity-version_2.29.description: version 2.29 refers to the specific release of the GNU C Library (Glibc) used in the development of packages for the MILIS Linux operating system on RISC-V architecture.

Entity-computer_system.label: computer system
Entity-computer_system.description: A computer system is an integrated set of hardware and software components designed to process data and perform computational tasks.

Entity-project.label: project
Entity-project.description: The mention 'project' refers to the MILIS Linux project, which is a Linux distribution initiative that began in 2016 and aims to create an independent, open-source operating system using Linux from Scratch techniques.

Entity-32-bit_port_in_milis.label: 32-bit ports in MILIS
Entity-32-bit_port_in_milis.description: The mention '32-bit ports in MILIS' refers to the potential adaptation of the MILIS Linux operating system to support 32-bit architecture configurations, which has not been previously implemented and is deemed unnecessary for the current development focus.

Entity-independent_user_space.label: independent user space
Entity-independent_user_space.description: Independent user space refers to a distinct environment within an operating system, specifically in the context of the MILIS Linux project, that operates independently from the system's core functionalities, allowing for the management and execution of applications without interference from the underlying system processes.

Entity-desktop-targeted_operating_system.label: desktop-targeted operating system
Entity-desktop-targeted_operating_system.description: A desktop-targeted operating system is a type of software designed specifically for use on personal computers, providing a user interface and system resources tailored for desktop environments.

Entity-discussing_them.label: discussing them
Entity-discussing_them.description: The term 'discussing them' refers to the RISC-V Foundation's engagement in deliberating proposals related to the development and standardization of RISC-V architecture.

Entity-technology_relevant_company.label: Technology relevant companies
Entity-technology_relevant_company.description: Technology relevant companies refer to businesses and organizations from various countries that are involved in the development and support of the RISC-V architecture, contributing to the RISC-V foundation.

Entity-linux_distribution_project.label: Linux distribution project
Entity-linux_distribution_project.description: The Linux distribution project refers to the MILIS project, an independent Linux distribution initiated in 2016 that utilizes Linux from Scratch techniques and aims to provide a free and user-friendly operating system with its own package manager.

Entity-llvm_compiler_infrastructure.label: LLVM Compiler Infrastructure
Entity-llvm_compiler_infrastructure.description: LLVM Compiler Infrastructure is a collection of modular and reusable compiler and toolchain technologies that enable the development of compiler frameworks and support various programming languages.

Entity-organizational_use.label: organizational use
Entity-organizational_use.description: The term 'organizational use' refers to the intended application of the MILIS Linux operating system, which aims to provide a free and user-friendly platform specifically designed for use by organizations, including government agencies and commercial entities.

Entity-4.0.0.description: 4.0.0 refers to the version of the QEMU system emulator used in the development and testing of the MILIS Linux operating system for RISC-V architecture.

Entity-hardware.label: hardware
Entity-hardware.description: Hardware refers to the physical components and devices that make up a computer system, enabling it to function and run software applications.

Entity-alternative_library.label: alternative libraries
Entity-alternative_library.description: Alternative libraries refer to different implementations of C libraries that can be used as substitutes for Glibc in the context of RISC-V architecture development.

Entity-glibc.label: Glibc
Entity-glibc.description: Glibc is a widely used implementation of the standard C library for the GNU operating system, providing essential functions for C programming.

Entity-physical_hardware.label: physical hardware
Entity-physical_hardware.description: Physical hardware refers to the tangible components of a computer system, including devices such as processors, memory, storage, and peripherals, that are essential for its operation.

Entity-processor_design.label: processor design
Entity-processor_design.description: Processor design refers to the engineering process and methodologies involved in creating the architecture, functionality, and performance characteristics of a computer processor.

Entity-linux_kernel.label: Linux kernel
Entity-linux_kernel.description: The Linux kernel is the core component of the Linux operating system, responsible for managing hardware resources and providing essential services to software applications.

Entity-motherboards.label: motherboards
Entity-motherboards.description: Motherboards are essential computer components that serve as the main circuit board, connecting and allowing communication between various hardware components of a computer system.

Entity-sponsor.label: sponsors
Entity-sponsor.description: The term 'sponsors' refers to organizations or entities that provide financial support and funding for research and development studies related to RISC-V processors.

Entity-64-bit_only_architecture.label: 64-bit only architecture
Entity-64-bit_only_architecture.description: A 64-bit only architecture refers to a computer architecture that exclusively supports 64-bit data processing and operations, without compatibility for 32-bit instructions or applications.

Entity-linux_kernel_3.1.label: Linux kernel 3.1
Entity-linux_kernel_3.1.description: Linux kernel 3.1 is a specific version of the Linux kernel, which is the core component of the Linux operating system responsible for managing hardware and system resources.

Entity-support.description: In the context of the paper, 'support' refers to the functionality provided by the Berkeley Bootloader (BBL) to facilitate the booting process and manage tasks related to timer interrupts and boot chain loading for the RISC-V architecture.

Entity-kernel_and_user_space_software.label: kernel and user space software
Entity-kernel_and_user_space_software.description: Kernel and user space software refers to the components of an operating system where the kernel operates in a privileged mode managing hardware resources, while user space software runs in a restricted mode, providing applications and services that interact with the kernel.

Entity-register_area.label: register areas
Entity-register_area.description: Register areas refer to specific sections of a processor's architecture that are allocated for storing temporary data and instructions, which help optimize memory usage and improve processing efficiency in computing systems.

Entity-independent_base.label: independent base
Entity-independent_base.description: The term 'independent base' refers to the unique foundational structure of the MILIS Linux operating system, which is not derived from any existing Linux distribution and features its own package management system.

Entity-individual_and_organizational_use.label: individual and organizational use
Entity-individual_and_organizational_use.description: The term 'individual and organizational use' refers to the intended application of the MILIS Linux operating system, which aims to provide a user-friendly and accessible platform for both private users and commercial entities.

Entity-linux_from_scratch_directive.label: Linux from Scratch directives
Entity-linux_from_scratch_directive.description: Linux from Scratch directives are a set of guidelines and instructions used to build a custom Linux operating system from the ground up, allowing users to create a tailored system by compiling and configuring software packages manually.

Entity-future_specification_revision.label: future specification revision
Entity-future_specification_revision.description: Future specification revision refers to the process of proposing and implementing changes to the specifications of the RISC-V architecture, which can enhance its design and functionality in future iterations.

Entity-debian.label: Debian
Entity-debian.description: Debian is a widely used open-source operating system based on the Linux kernel, known for its stability and extensive software repository, developed by a community of volunteers.

Entity-toolchain.label: Toolchain
Entity-toolchain.description: A toolchain is a set of programming tools that are used together to perform complex tasks in software development, typically including a compiler, linker, and libraries.

Entity-a_port.label: a port
Entity-a_port.description: A port refers to a version of a software application that has been adapted to run on a specific platform or architecture, in this case, the adaptation of the Debian operating system for a particular hardware architecture.

Entity-linux_from_scratch.label: Linux from Scratch
Entity-linux_from_scratch.description: Linux from Scratch is a project that provides a comprehensive guide for building a custom Linux operating system from the ground up, allowing users to create a tailored Linux distribution according to their specific needs.

Entity-individual.label: individual
Entity-individual.description: The term 'individual' refers to a single user or end user who utilizes the MILIS Linux operating system, which is designed to be accessible and user-friendly for both personal and organizational purposes.

Entity-target_user_of_milis.label: Target users of MILIS
Entity-target_user_of_milis.description: The target users of MILIS are primarily government agencies, commercial organizations, and private users who seek a free and easy-to-use operating system.

Entity-secure_network_structure.label: Secure network structure
Entity-secure_network_structure.description: The 'Secure network structure' refers to a configurable framework within the MILIS Linux operating system that allows users to establish secure network configurations through a web browser interface.

Entity-uclibc.label: Uclibc

Entity-silver_member.label: silver member
Entity-silver_member.description: The term 'silver member' refers to ASELSAN's membership status within the RISC-V foundation, indicating a level of participation and support for the RISC-V open source architecture initiative.

Entity-virtual_board.label: virtual board
Entity-virtual_board.description: The term 'virtual board' refers to a simulated computing environment that allows the execution of a live image of an operating system, enabling testing and development without the need for physical hardware.

Entity-chip_production.label: chip production
Entity-chip_production.description: Chip production refers to the process of manufacturing semiconductor chips, which are essential components in electronic devices and systems.

Entity-open_source_hardware_initiative.label: open source hardware initiative
Entity-open_source_hardware_initiative.description: The open source hardware initiative refers to a collaborative effort aimed at developing and promoting hardware designs that are publicly accessible and can be freely modified and distributed by anyone.

Entity-open_source_operating_system_deve.label: open source operating system development project

Entity-musl.description: Musl is a lightweight and efficient implementation of the standard C library designed for Linux-based systems.

Entity-open_source_ecosystem.description: The open source ecosystem refers to a collaborative environment where software, hardware, and related resources are developed and shared openly, allowing for community participation, innovation, and the free exchange of ideas and technologies.

Entity-real_hardware.description: Real hardware refers to physical computing devices and components that execute software, as opposed to virtualized or emulated environments used for development and testing.

Entity-processor_capability.label: processor capabilities
Entity-processor_capability.description: Processor capabilities refer to the features and performance attributes of a processor that determine its ability to execute tasks efficiently and effectively.

Entity-development_community.label: development community
Entity-development_community.description: The development community refers to a collective group of individuals and organizations actively engaged in the enhancement and collaboration of open-source projects, particularly in the context of RISC-V architecture, facilitating the sharing of ideas and contributions.

Entity-load-store_command.label: load-store commands

Entity-live_image.label: live image

Entity-open_hardware.label: Open Hardware
Entity-open_hardware.description: Open Hardware refers to a concept and movement that promotes the design and sharing of hardware specifications and designs in an open and collaborative manner, allowing anyone to study, modify, and distribute the hardware.

Entity-license_term_limitation.label: license term limitations

Entity-computer.label: computer

Entity-64-bit.label: 64-bit
Entity-64-bit.description: 64-bit refers to a data type or architecture that uses 64 bits to represent data, allowing for a larger range of values and greater precision compared to lower bit-width systems.

Entity-base_file_system.label: base file system
Entity-base_file_system.description: The base file system refers to the foundational structure of a file system that provides essential files and directories necessary for the operation of an operating system or software environment.

Entity-lf.label: LFS

Entity-system_emulation.label: System Emulation

Entity-halt_code.label: Halt Code

Entity-great_improvement.label: great improvements

Entity-llvm.label: LLVM

Entity-processor_manufacturer.label: processor manufacturers

Entity-user_space.label: user space

Entity-it_own_package_manager.label: its own package manager
Entity-it_own_package_manager.description: The term 'its own package manager' refers to a software tool integrated within the MILIS Linux operating system that allows users to install, update, and manage software packages independently.

Entity-research_group.label: research groups
Entity-research_group.description: Research groups refer to collaborative entities, often within academic institutions, that focus on advancing knowledge and innovation in specific areas, such as the development and implementation of RISC-V architecture in this context.

Entity-the_root_file_system.label: the root file system

Entity-vulnerability.label: vulnerability
Entity-vulnerability.description: The mention 'vulnerability' refers to security weaknesses in computing systems, specifically highlighting issues like Meltdown and Spectre that arise from inadequate hardware-level protections despite high software-level security measures.

Entity-the_academic_environment.label: the academic environment
Entity-the_academic_environment.description: The academic environment refers to the collective setting of educational institutions, research organizations, and scholarly communities where open source software development and collaboration occur, particularly aimed at fostering innovation and knowledge sharing.

summary:
Abstract—As is commonly known, hardware in a computer system requires a processor to run the operating system. The primary architectures that form the basis of most processors are CISC and RISC. CISC includes long sub-level commands for effective memory management and simple compiler implementations to be developed. Thus CISC has a complex set of commands; hence the name Complex Instruction Set Computer. On the other hand, CISC has had backward compatibility since the 1970s. Reduced Instruction Set Computer (RISC), the other popular architecture, simplifies command sets and handles access to memory with load-store commands. Since the instruction set is simplified, the hardware runs faster. In addition, RISC-based processors contain less chip-sets and may be designed faster. Currently, with the prevalence of the Internet of Things (IoT), the demand for RISC architectures has increased and its usage in embedded devices has become widespread. The ARM processor is a successful example of the RISC architecture adaptation. However, ARM processor production has certain license term limitations and contains a few design flaws in its architecture [1]. In 2010, the RISC-V processor architecture, which was developed as an open source instruction set at Berkeley University, paves the way for open source hardware in terms of its BSD license and design professionalism. As a result, it will be possible to produce their own processors for communities and organizations without license restrictions. In this paper, we discuss the building blocks of the development life-cycle of an open source operating system on the RISC-V architecture. As an operating system base, we implement MILIS Linux, an open source operating system development project. It has an independent user space and its own package manager. For a completely independent open source computing system, open source RISC-V hardware architecture provides the freedom that is needed.

RISC-V is an open-source instruction set architecture (ISA) that offers a more secure and efficient alternative to traditional processors, focusing on basic computational operations and optimized instruction implementation. It allows for extensions and improvements by industry experts, fostering a collaborative ecosystem. Despite historical challenges in open-source hardware, RISC-V has gained traction with contributions from major institutions worldwide. MILIS Linux, a unique distribution initiated in 2016, aims to create a free and user-friendly operating system, independent of existing distributions. The project is now developing a fork to support RISC-V architecture, targeting embedded devices and IoT applications, thus promoting open-source operating systems in the context of Industry 4.0.

SiFive has developed several motherboards for RISC-V processors, leading to increased support for Linux distributions. Legacy distributions like Debian are porting to RISC-V, while Fedora is creating a native OS and a web-based compilation tracking system. Buildroot has also been adapted for 64-bit RISC-V architecture. This paper focuses on enhancing kernel support and reducing porting times through a reference implementation based on MILIS, aiming to build a Linux from Scratch and improve user-space application levels.

MILIS Linux is successfully running on 64-bit systems, focusing on RISC-V architecture. The project aims to create kernel and userspace packages for a 64-bit little-endian RISC-V system, with future considerations for 32-bit and 128-bit variants. Key components include: A. System Emulation using QEMU for development without hardware; B. Toolchain with GCC 9.1 and Binutils 2.32, utilizing Glibc 2.29 for RISC-V support; C. Bootloader options like Berkley Bootloader (BBL) for kernel execution, which requires rebuilding with the kernel; D. Ongoing work on various kernel and userspace tasks since RISC-V Linux was accepted into the Linux tree in 2017; E. Cross-compilation of packages to create a bootable operating system; F. Creation of a bootable image from MILIS packages for distribution. The overall process aims to establish a functional RISC-V computing environment.

This paper discusses the RISC-V processor, highlighting its potential due to its open-source, community-driven design, making it suitable for mission-critical projects, especially in the Internet of Things. Many companies are investing in R&D for RISC-V, joining the RISC-V foundation. The paper emphasizes the need for a reliable open-source operating system, with Linux as the ideal kernel. While port migration of Linux distributions is underway, there is a call to develop a robust user ecosystem on the Linux kernel through the MILIS Linux project. This initiative aims to enhance the IT process and will benefit from the open computing proposal.

A. Physical Implementation and Optimizations The work outline performed on the QEMU virtual machine discussed in this study will be applied on a real board based on RISC-V processor. Compilation and testing will give more accurate results using physical hardware. Thus, we will have a better understanding of the components that will need to be optimized. The compilation tools that we use in the bootstrap process will offer more RISC-V support over time and will be optimized. In addition, alternative libraries instead of Glibc, which we currently use as C libraries, will be evaluated. Also, with the RISC-V support in the LLVM Compiler Infrastructure [31], native compile support will be increased at the level of programming languages which use LLVM as back-end compiler. RISC-V porting will be further explored for the kernel level difficulties encountered while providing the necessary solutions. The necessary sponsors and research project funding supports will be provided for the R&D studies and RISC-V processors with different features will be obtained and the studies will be performed on real equipment.

B. The Future: Open Hardware and Open Source Operating System Open hardware means license-free; namely with RISC-V virtually anyone can produce potentially better evaluations and much more accurate comparisons with existing works. There is a range of high quality, open-source RISC-V implementations to modify, rather than just based on estimating or simulations. Also opening standard will bring about a more active development community so that when sharing patches or ideas, projects will get contributions more quickly. As of now one aspect of the RISC-V Foundation is responding to proposals and discussing them. The other aspect is producing proposed changes either in a future specification revision or in hardware. On the other hand, opening the standards and having a commercially open license would certainly make the processor design and production race more fair. Also RISC-V will bring a new synergy of open source computer architecture research areas, such as universities started to establish research groups on RISC-V, such as OpenCelerity [32] and SCARV [33]. Research is expected to be carried out on real hardware with the increase of RISC-V processor manufacturers. As a result, Linux kernel and userspace seems the best candidate software stack for RISC-V.
